See [this comment about the relevance of `<Plug>`](https://github.com/nvim-neorocks/nvim-best-practices/issues/5#issuecomment-2131367234).

To address your specific concern about `vim.diagnostic.jump`, and as I've mentioned in a previous discussion about plugin initialisation:

Plugin authors can choose to diverge if they deem it necessary, which is made clear right at the beginning of this guide:

>   it is not intended as a set of rules...

Furthermore, I have already added a paragraph that should address your concern: 

> Another option is to simply expose a Lua function or |user-commands|.

If it's not obvious from that that exposing a Lua function isn't always a bad practise, then perhaps that needs to be rephrased to be more clear?

About static type checking: It's nice to have, but yagni in a user config.

+- lua-language-server https://luals.github.io

+so can easily lead to conflicts with user |mapping|s.

+NOTE: An example for uncontroversial keymaps are buffer-local |mapping|s for
+      specific file types or floating windows.
+

+https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domain-specific_language via a `setup` function.
+
+However, doing so means that
+
+- You will have to implement and document it yourself.
+- Users will likely face inconsistencies if another plugin has a slightly
+  different DSL.
+- |init.lua| scripts that call such a `setup` function may throw an error if
+  the plugin is not installed or disabled.
+
+As an alternative, you can provide |<Plug>| mappings to allow users to define
+their own keymaps with |vim.keymap.set()|.
+
+- This requires one line of code in user configs.
+- Even if your plugin is not installed or disabled, creating the keymap won't
+  throw an error.
+
+Another option is to simply expose a Lua function or |user-commands|.
+
+However, some benefits of |<Plug>| mappings over this are that you can
+
+- Enforce options like `expr = true`.
+- Expose functionality only for specific |map-modes|.
+- Expose different behavior for different |map-modes| with a single |<Plug>|
+  mapping, without adding impurity or complexity to the underlying Lua
+  implementation.

comment_data.body:
I've rephrased the text to hopefully clarify that I'm recommending either `<Plug>` or a Lua function, or both, depending on the use case:

This is the updated text:

```
Another option is to simply expose a Lua function or |user-commands|.

Some benefits of |<Plug>| mappings are that you can

- Enforce options like `expr = true`.
- Expose functionality only for specific |map-modes|.
- Expose different behavior for different |map-modes| with a single |<Plug>|
  mapping, without adding impurity or complexity to the underlying Lua
  implementation.

Some benefits of exposing a Lua function are:

- Extensibility, if the function takes an options table as an argument.
- A cleaner UX, if there are many options and enumerating all combinations
  of options would result in a lot of |<Plug>| mappings.

NOTE: If your function takes an options table, users may still benefit 
      from |<Plug>| mappings for the most common combinations.
```

comment_data.body:
Note that you can achieve the same benefits with native Lua functions; you just have to separate your internal API from functions you (re-)export e.g. via wrappers (around `require`d modules) )defined in your `plugin`.

So `<plug>` is a red herring here: it's not about vimscript vs. lua but about separating public and internal API to avoid leaking implementation details.

comment_data.body:
Unsure if this has been discussed before, but it's worth noting that `<Plug>` mappings have the benefit of being strings, which means they can be looked up using `vim.fn.hasmapto` (I don't believe you can do the same for function references, unless neovim does some internal magic to allow this?). This means plugins can check if a `<Plug>` is mapped and not remap their own standard keys, instead respecting the user's override.

If such a thing can't be done on callback-based keymaps, then it's a pretty big win for `<Plug>`. Plugins being "intelligent" and ergonomic in this way is definitely something worth striving for and recommending that plugin authors do.

comment_data.body:
> Note that you can achieve the same benefits with native Lua functions;

It's possible, but it involves adding impure checks (like `vim.api.nvim_get_mode()`) to the function (or wrapper function) implementation, whereas the `vim.keymap` interface handles mode-specific behavior as part of its core API.
To my knowledge, there's no way to enforce `expr = true` with a Lua function? (I may be mistaken).

[`<Plug>` mappings aren't Vimscript, they're a mapping feature.](https://github.com/nvim-neorocks/nvim-best-practices/issues/5#issuecomment-2131367234)

> separating public and internal API to avoid leaking implementation details.

This is an important point, but you can do that with a DSL in a `setup` function too.
I wrote this section to be about Lua and/or `<Plug>` mappings vs. DSLs in a `setup` function.

I recommend `<Plug>` mappings _as an option_, because they are underutilised,
due to the common misconception that they're an "outdated Vimscript" thing.
Again, this is _not a recommendation against exposing a Lua function_.

I've updated the section again, to be more clear:

```
Some benefits of |<Plug>| mappings are that you can

- Enforce options like `expr = true`.
- Use |vim.keymap|'s built-in mode handling to expose functionality only for
  specific |map-modes|.
- Handle different |map-modes| differently with a single mapping, without
  adding mode checks to the underlying implementation.
- Detect user-defined mappings through |hasmapto| before creating defaults.
```

It is not good idea to use sub command if the command is readable.  for example FooInstall and FooUninstall is easy to understand. I think when  same action need more argc, we can use sub command. for example FooInstallA and FooInstallB.
If this guide is for nvim plugin code style guide. more review is needed, especially from other nvim plugin developers.

@wsdjeg there is already a (as of writing, unresolved) [discussion about whether to include that section because Neovim doesn't have a proper API for it](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/29073#discussion_r1617940460). 

As for your example:
With top-level PascalCase commands, typing `Foo<tab>` or `FB<tab>` (fuzzy) could match both one plugin's `FooBar` and another plugin's `FootballBar`, whereas `Foo<space><tab>` will show me only `Foo` subcommands. That decreases discoverability if you're looking for actions related to `Foo`.

See also [this comment](https://github.com/nvim-neorocks/nvim-best-practices/issues/5#issuecomment-2131367234):

> plugin authors can choose to diverge if they want. But we need to give a starting point.

Not to derail this PR but wanted to mention - There's a [Neovim plugin template](https://github.com/ColinKennedy/nvim-best-practices-plugin-template/) (disclosure: I wrote the plugin) that could be added as links in this PR to illustrate the covered topics.

Most of the sections here could be linked to a single block of code / configuration as an example. The only exception would be the built-in command-mode parser, called cmdparse, which is IMO better suited as a plugin or LuaRocks package.
